windows.symptom: mouse stutter + surfacebook 2 + better performance + sampling rate > 250Hz        Dear Community,I'm using a Surface Book 2 15" / 250GB HHD configuration.I have a problem using my Gaming Mouse (ROCCAT) for a while now on this machine.The pointer stutters "randomly" (freezes every few seconds for about a second then jumping ahead).Today I made a connection to the energy profile I use and the sample rate (Hz) set in the mouse driver.Since my system is not set to english i'll call the 3 engery profile settings (the ones you find under the battery icon in the system tray) as follows:1 - longest battery life -> for the battery saving setting obviously (leaf icon)2 - better performance -> for the intermediate setting3 - best performance -> well also obvious (lighningbolt icon)With the mouse set to 1000Hz sample rate there are no issues using energy profile 1. Using profile 2 the pointer is "hanging" about once every 20 seconds. When profile 3 is active the mouse is constantly stuttering -> to a point where working with it is almost impossible. (Note that "best performance" which should make no compromises in cpu speeds etc. actually yields the worst results here)Lowering the sample rate in the mouse driver helps gradually with every step (250Hz) to the point where at the 250Hz sample rate the problem subsides and the mouse is running smoothly even using energy profile 3(best performance).Now I know what you would think - what's his problem sounds like he's got the fix right at hand.True, though I'm still wondering what's going on with my machine that this problem even occurs - especially since the problem is not connected to increased cpu usage.I tested the mouse on other Laptops and it seems fine.Another mouse model from Roccat has the same stutter problem when used with higher sample rates.Also I tried a really cheap logitech office mouse and it doesn't have any problem (presumably because the sample rate is initially low)Does anyone have a guess what's going on here and if there might be a real fix for the problem instead of a work around?Thanks in advance and cheers to all who made it to the bottom of this essay =)

windows.symptom: spacing        How to fix the spacing between icons on desktop
solutions: Hello i'm Timon and i'm glad to help you. Yes, you can do that, but it means editing the Windows registry, and you'll have to edit the registry each time you want to make a change, which can be inconvenient. There's no simpler way to do it.Here's why I think you shouldn't do that, even if you're comfortable with editing the registry, and this is only my opinion:Although you can, this is not a metric that Windows intends for people to change. As a result, changing it may have unanticipated consequences for the appearance and usability of your desktop.Follow this link for more information: https://mywindowshub.com/how-to-change-desktop-...Disclaimer: This is a non-Microsoft website which would provide accurate and safe information. Watch out for ads on the site which are frequently classified as a PUP (Potentially Unwanted Products).A possible workaround: Go to your desktop and left click on an empty area of your desktop background. Hold down the CTRL key on your keyboard (do not let go). Now, use the mouse wheel on the mouse, and move slide it up or down to adjust the icon size and its spacing.The icons and their spacing should adjust to your mouse scroll wheel movement. When you find the setting you like, release the CTRL key on the keyboard.

windows.symptom: Windows Mail has accounts "Disappear"        I am using my Windows Mail Version 16005.12228.20276.0 on Windows 10 version 1909.I have several accounts linked to Mail.3x Yahoo2x Outlook1x GmailA few weeks ago, when I logged in, it only showed my Outlook mails. solutions: Hi Steve, Thank you for writing to Microsoft Community Forums. I understand your query related to accounts being removed from Mail app. For further clarity on the issue, please respond to the question below. Were there any updates installed recently on your PC? To check which updates were installed recently, go to Settings > Update & Security > Windows updates > View installed update history Meanwhile, I would suggest you to try running the troubleshooter for the Windows Store apps and check if the issue persists. Press Windows + I keys together to openSettingsNow click on Update & Security and selectTroubleshootScroll down and look for Windows Store appsClick on it and select Run the troubleshooterFollow the on-screen instructions Let us know how it goes. Regards,Prakhar KhareMicrosoft Community – Moderator

windows.symptom: Touchscreen nightmare after Windows 10 1903 install        Hi:I'm having problems with the Touchscreen (TS) on my HP Pavilion all-in-one 27-n190st Desktop/Product # P2N43AV#ABA/OS 1903 (10.0.18362)The TS stops working. I go into device manager "HID-compliant touch screen". Under Properties, General it says "Currently this hardware device is not connected to the computer (Code 45). Reconnect this hardware device to computer." The disable/enable is not available when Code 45 is displayed. The only way to fix the issue is to uninstall the HID-compliant touch screen driver. When I restart the computer the driver is back and will work for most of the day. If I stop using the computer for a few hours the touchscreen stops working and the exact same problem returns.Under "Events" for TS it says on 8/8, when this problem started, "Device Migrated". I reinstalled the driver many times since then.After re-install of driver, another message says HID NOT migrated "due to partial or ambiguous match". When the TS is working, under driver "Details", it says no driver files are required or have been loaded for this device.1. I've "scanned for hardware changes" under HID Devices and HID touchscreen. No results.2. Under power management "allow the computer to turn off device" is unchecked 3. I tried to run a test on the touchscreen from F2. The problem is There's no "Mouse/Touch-pad" on the list of tests. There's only a "Mouse" test.4. I went into startup menu in the bios. I hit F9. It asked me to select boot device. UEF I boot sources were: Windows Boot ManagerUEF: I IPv4 ... Family ControllerUEF: I IPv 6 ... Family ControllerLegacy Boot SourcesI chose "Windows Boot Manager". It rebooted and touchscreen worked but, it again stopped working after not using it for several hours.When the touchscreen stops working ... the USB Input Device also stops working. It also "Migrated"  on 8/8, the same day the HID touch screen migrated. The USB Input device properties says "The device cannot start  (CODE 10). "Operation failed".Most importantly, I noticed that Windows 10 1903 version was installed on 8/8/19, which is the day the Touchscreen Driver and the USB input device migrated and these problems started.5. I ran the "Detect My Drivers" in HP Customer Support. The result was: "Detection was successful but you don’t need any new drivers at this time."6. I've selected "update driver" when in HID Touchscreen within Device Manager. Results: "Best Device for your driver is already installed" 7. I ran HP Support Assistant. It says No Updates Available. 8. In HP PC Hardware Diagnostics I ran the Mouse touchpad Drag and Drop test. I ignored the results because ALL it says is "Failure ID: M08770-8159PN-QFFX61-G1UA13 RESULT: Failed" But when I click on the ID it says "The test found a problem with the mouse button. The mouse may need to be replaced." The problem is The mouse works perfectly.  It says nothing about the touchscreen ... even if I run the test while the touchscreen isn't working. 9. Touchscreen doesn't work in Bios10. I've installed all Windows 10 updates.Again, All of this started on 8/8 when I installed Windows 10 1903.Any ideas would be greatly appreciated.    Thanks
solutions: Update:I tried using F2 and testing the touch screen using HP PC Hardware Diagnostics UEFI. The Touch screen was not working on the main computer BUT the "Touch Pointer test" ... passed and the "Touch and Drag Test" ... passed. I went back into computer and the touchscreen still didn't work.Now under Device Manager it says touchscreen working, but it's not.

I forgot to add that I did an "System Extensive Test" in "HP Hardware Diagnostics Test" program.  It took a few hours. No problems were detected. **************************************************************Update:I tried using F2 and testing the touch screen using HP PC Hardware Diagnostics UEFI. The Touch screen was not working on the main computer BUT the "Touch Pointer test" ... passed and the "Touch and Drag Test" ... passed. I went back into computer and the touchscreen still didn't work.Now under Device Manager it says touchscreen working, but it's not.

windows.symptom: BIOS error        HelloI recently bought a gaming PC and 1 month into using it my RAM started to be undetectable (it was doing 1 long and 2 short beeps on start up and wouldnt display anything on the monitor)I eventually got the PC to recognise the RAM by doing the following:- removed the graphics card and re installed- unplugged all the connectors to the motherboard and plugged them back in- remove the CMOS battery for a minute or so- slotted the RAM back inWhich worked, the beeping stopped. HOWEVER it came up with the error message BlInitializeLibrary failed 0xc0000001 Can some one help? Windows wont boot now :(Thank you
solutions: Hi K4YFc My name is Jon and I am an independent technical adviser. Sorry to hear you are experiencing issues and I would really like to help you find a resolution.This error has been known to occur as a result of one or more of the following: Cause 1: SAM file is damaged The SAM(Security Accounts Manager) file stores the user credentials data and is essential to Windows booting process. If that file is missing or corrupt, then the boot process is halted.Cause 2: System files are damaged Sometimes, this error may occur when the key boot-related system files become damaged because of disk write error, power outages or virus attacks.Cause 3: File system integrity compromised Alternatively, this error appears when the whole file system gets damaged on a grander scale for the same reasons.Cause 4: RAM is damaged In the worst case scenario, the PC’s memory could be permanently damaged. I would advise to switch the PC off, remove the power cable then remove the RAM module (ensuring you are earthed) and leave for a few minutes. Then re-install the RAM module and try booting the PC again.Hope this helps.

windows.symptom: PROBLEM        WINDOWS 10 UPADATES GETTING TROUBLE IN MY DEVICE
solutions: I HOPE TO YOU WILL SOLVE MY PROBLEM

Hi Madhu448713 please try each of these and check for updates after each 1) Run the update troubleshooter settings -> Update & security -> Troubleshoot on the left, click windows update then click the run the troubleshooter button. 2) click start, type powershell right click on powershell and select run as administrator type (or paste) the following and press enter after each one net stop wuauserv net stop cryptSvc net stop bits net stop msiserver Ren C:\Windows\SoftwareDistribution SoftwareDistribution.old Ren C:\Windows\System32\catroot2 Catroot2.old net start wuauserv net start cryptSvc net start bits net start msiserver 3) follow the steps given in the "fix windows update issues, walk through" https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/help/10164/...please let us know how you get on. if you are still having issues please give us a bit more information, is it a feature update or all updates? do you get any error?what is happening when windows tries to install updates?

windows.symptom: Game Crashes on Windows 10        Almost all of my games crashed within an hour of playing and I don't know why
solutions: Hi John Most likely this is caused by your video card device driver, while that may be up to date, an older version of that driver might be more compatible with your PC and stabilize your system . . .Open Device Manager (accessible by right clicking your Start Button) Expand the Display Adapters Section Right click your video card and choose Properties On the Driver Tab, choose 'Roll back Driver' Restart your PC once done . . . If that option is grayed out or does not resolve the issue, go to the support page for your device on the manufacturers website, then download and install the video driver they recommend, it may well be an older version to the one you are currently runningIf you are actually getting blue screens, to diagnose the underlying issue, I need to analyse your Mini-dump file(s):Open Windows File Explorer Navigate to C:\Windows\Minidump Copy any minidump files onto your Desktop, then zip those up Upload the zip file to the Cloud (OneDrive, DropBox . . . etc.), then choose to share those and get a share linkThen post the link here to the zip file, so we can take a look for you . . .
This is my minidump folder: https://www.dropbox.com/s/gswvqyp59scxz3r/Minidump.zip?dl=0

Hi John Analysis of your minidump files indicates the Nvidia graphics card device driver on your PC is causing the system crashes . . .A lot of the time, this is caused by the newest device driver being installed and installing a slightly older version of that can resolve this . . .Open Device Manager (accessible by right clicking your Start Button) Expand the Display Adapters Section Right click your video card and choose Properties On the Driver Tab, choose 'Roll back Driver' Restart your PC once done . . . If that option is grayed out or does not resolve the issue, go to the support page for your device on the manufacturers website, then download and install the video driver they recommend, it may well be an older version to the one you are currently running

windows.symptom: Safe Mode will not recognize password        Windows 10I can access the safe mode screen bit on entering password I am told Password invalid.I have tried safe mode with networking and used my microsoft password without success.From Googling this problem it would that this could be a OS bug.Please can you advise how to work around itCurious Roblin
solutions: Try to enter the safe mode with the network function to repair, it may be that the network controller is outdated.Press and hold the power button for 5 to 10 seconds to perform a complete shutdownDo this three or more times. As soon as you see the Windows logo with the rotating dots, press and hold the power button until the computer turns off. Do this process twice..-Turn on your computer for the third time, and let it load. .-You should receive this message: Preparing Automatic Repair. After entering Mode Update the network driver may be outdated
